Herbal treatments[ ] Various national and party-held Chinese media heavily advertised an "overnight research" report by [Wuhan Institute of Virology](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wuhan_Institute_of_Virology) and Shanghai Institute of Materia Medica, [Chinese Academy of Sciences](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_Academy_of_Sciences), on how [shuanghuanglian](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/shuanghuanglian), an herb mixture from [traditional Chinese medicine](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/traditional_Chinese_medicine) (TCM), can effectively inhibit the novel coronavirus. The report led to a purchase craze of shuanghuanglian. The president of [Madagascar](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madagascar) [Andry Rajoelina](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andry_Rajoelina) launched and promoted in April 2020 a herbal drink based on an [artemisia plant](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artemisia_(genus)) as a miracle cure that can treat and prevent COVID-19 despite a lack of medical evidence. The drink has been exported to other African countries. Vitamins[ ] During the [2020 COVID-19 pandemic](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_COVID-19_pandemic), vitamin C was the subject of more FDA warning letters than any other [quack treatment](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/quackery) for COVID-19. In February 2020, claims that [Vitamin D](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vitamin_D) pills could help prevent the coronavirus circulated on social media in [Thailand](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Thailand). In May 2020 the [Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centre_for_Evidence-Based_Medicine), while noting that "current advice is that the whole population of the UK should take vitamin D supplements to prevent vitamin D deficiency", found "no clinical evidence that vitamin D supplements are beneficial in preventing or treating COVID-19". [Vitamin D deficiency](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vitamin_D_deficiency), however, may raise the risk of a COVID-19 infection, as well as the severity of the infection. Common cold and flu treatments[ ] There were also claims that a 30-year-old Indian textbook lists [aspirin](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/aspirin), [antihistamines](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/antihistamines), and nasal spray as treatments for COVID-19. The textbook actually talks about [coronaviruses](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/coronavirus) in general, as a family of viruses. A rumor circulated on social media posts on Weibo, Facebook and Twitter claiming that Chinese experts said saline solutions could kill the coronavirus. There is no evidence that saline solutions have such an effect. A tweet from French health minister [Olivier Véran](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olivier_V%C3%A9ran), a bulletin from the French health ministry, and a small speculative study in [The Lancet Respiratory Medicine](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Lancet_Respiratory_Medicine) raised concerns about [ibuprofen](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ibuprofen) worsening COVID-19, which spread extensively on social media. The [European Medicines Agency](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Medicines_Agency) and the World Health Organization recommended COVID-19 patients keep taking ibuprofen as directed, citing lack of convincing evidence of any danger. Animal-based products or foods[ ] Indian political activist [Swami Chakrapani](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chakrapani_(politician)) and [Member of the Legislative Assembly](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Member_of_the_Legislative_Assembly_(India)) [Suman Haripriya](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suman_Haripriya) claimed that drinking cow urine and applying cow dung on the body can cure COVID-19. WHO's chief scientist [Soumya Swaminathan](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soumya_Swaminathan_(scientist)) criticised politicians incautiously spreading such misinformation without an evidence base. Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) prescriptions[ ] Since its third version, the COVID management guidelines from the Chinese [National Health Commission](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Health_Commission) recommends using [Traditional Chinese Medicines](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_medicine) to treat the disease. In Wuhan, [China Central Television](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China_Central_Television) reported that local authorities have pushed for a set of TCM prescriptions to be used for every case since early February. One formula was promoted at the national level by mid-February. The local field hospitals were explicitly TCM-oriented. According to [state media](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/state_media), as of 16 March 2020, 91.91% of all Hubei patients have used TCM, with the rate reaching 99% in field hospitals and 94% in bulk quarantine areas. In March 2020, the online insert of the official [People's Daily](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/People%27s_Daily), distributed in the [The Daily Telegraph](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph), published an article stating that Traditional Chinese medicine "helps fight coronavirus." Chloroquine and There were claims that [chloroquine](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/chloroquine) was used to cure more than 12,000 COVID-19 patients in Nigeria. On 11 March, Adrian Bye, a tech startup leader who is not a doctor, suggested to cryptocurrency investors Gregory Rigano and James Todaro that "chloroquine will keep most people out of hospital." Mustard oil[ ] The yoga guru [Ramdev](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramdev) claimed that one can treat coronavirus by pouring mustard oil through the nose, causing the virus to flow into the stomach where it would be destroyed by [gastric acid](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/gastric_acid). Untested treatments[ ] Misinformation that the government is spreading an "anti-corona" drug in the country during [Janata curfew](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janata_curfew), a stay-at-home curfew enforced in India, went viral on social media. Following the first reported case of COVID-19 in Nigeria on 28 February, untested cures and treatments began to spread via platforms such as In March 2020, the US [Federal Bureau of Investigation](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation) arrested actor Keith Lawrence Middlebrook for [wire fraud](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/wire_fraud) with a fake COVID-19 cure. Spiritual healing[ ] Another televangelist, [Kenneth Copeland](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_Copeland), claimed on Victory Channel during a programme called "Standing Against Coronavirus", that he can cure television viewers of COVID-19 directly from the television studio. The viewers had to touch the television screen to receive the spiritual healing. Other[ ] Name of the disease[ ] Social media posts and [internet memes](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/internet_meme) claimed that COVID-19 derives from "Chinese Originated Viral Infectious Disease 19", or similar, as supposedly the "19th virus to come out of China". In fact, the WHO named the disease as follows: CO stands for corona, VI for virus, D for disease and 19 for when the outbreak was first identified (31 December 2019). Simpsons prediction[ ] Claims that [The Simpsons](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Simpsons) had predicted the COVID-19 pandemic in 1993, accompanied by a doctored screenshot from the show (where the text "Corona Virus" was layered over the original text " [Apocalypse Meow](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Fool_Monty)", without blocking it from view), were later found to be false. The claim had been widely spread on social media. Return of wildlife[ ] During the pandemic, many false and misleading images or news reports about the environmental impact of the COVID-19 pandemic were shared by [clickbait](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/clickbait) journalism sources and social media. A viral post that originated on [Yunnan](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yunnan), got drunk on corn wine, and passed out in a tea garden. A Chinese news report debunked the claim that the elephants got drunk on corn wine and noted that wild elephants were a common sight in the village; the image attached to the post was originally taken at the Asian Elephant Research Center in Yunnan in December 2019. Following reports of reduced pollution levels in Italy as a result of lockdowns, images purporting to show swans and dolphins swimming in [Venice](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venice) canals went viral on social media. The image of the swans was revealed to have been taken in [Burano](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burano), where swans are common, while footage of the dolphins was filmed at a port in [Sardinia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sardinia) hundreds of miles away. The Venice mayor's office clarified that the reported water clarity in the canals was due to the lack of sediment being kicked up by boat traffic, not a reduction in water pollution as initially reported. Following the [lockdown of India](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_lockdown_in_India), a video clip purporting to show the extremely rare [Malabar civet](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malabar_large-spotted_civet) (a [critically endangered](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/critically_endangered), possibly [extinct](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extinction), species) walking the empty streets of [Meppayur](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meppayur) went viral on social media. Experts later identified the civet in the video as actually being the much commoner [small Indian civet](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/small_Indian_civet). Another viral Indian video clip showed a pod of [humpback whales](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/humpback_whale) allegedly returning to the [Arabian Sea](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arabian_Sea) offshore from [Mumbai](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mumbai) following the shutdown of shipping routes; however, this video was found to have actually been taken in 2019 in the [Java Sea](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Sea). Virus remains in body permanently[ ] It has been wrongly claimed that anyone infected with COVID-19 will have the virus in their bodies for life. While there is no curative treatment, most infected people recover from the disease and eliminate the virus from their bodies. Efforts to combat misinformation[ ] - Further information: [Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on journalism](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_journalism) On 2 February 2020, the [World Health Organization](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Health_Organization) (WHO) described a "massive [infodemic](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/infodemic)", citing an over-abundance of reported information, which was false, about the virus that "makes it hard for people to find trustworthy sources and reliable guidance when they need it". The WHO stated that the high demand for timely and trustworthy information has incentivised the creation of a direct WHO 24/7 myth-busting hotline where its communication and social media teams have been monitoring and responding to misinformation through its website and social media pages. The WHO specifically debunked several claims as false, including the claim that a person can tell if they have the virus or not simply by holding their breath; the claim that drinking large amounts of water will protect against the virus; and the claim that gargling salt water prevents infection. Social media[ ] In early February 2020, Facebook, Twitter, and Google announced that they were working with WHO to address misinformation. In a blog post, Facebook stated that it would remove content flagged by global health organizations and local authorities that violate its content policy on misinformation leading to "physical harm". Facebook is also giving free advertising to WHO. Nonetheless, a week after Trump's speculation that sunlight could kill the virus, the New York Times found "780 Facebook groups, 290 Facebook pages, nine Instagram accounts and thousands of tweets pushing UV light therapies," content which those companies declined to remove from their platforms. On 11 August 2020, Facebook removed seven million posts with misinformation about COVID-19. At the end of February 2020, [Amazon](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amazon_(company)) removed more than a million products that claimed to cure or protect against coronavirus, and removed tens of thousands of listings for health products whose prices were "significantly higher than recent prices offered on or off Amazon", although numerous items were "still being sold at unusually high prices" as of 28 February. Millions of instances of COVID-19 misinformation have occurred across a number of online platforms. Other [fake news](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/fake_news) researchers noted certain rumors started in China; many of them later spread to Korea and the United States, prompting several universities in Korea to start the multilingual "Facts Before Rumors" campaign to evaluate common claims seen online. Wikipedia[ ] The media have praised Wikipedia's coverage of COVID-19 and its combating the inclusion of [misinformation](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/misinformation) through efforts led by the Wiki Project Med Foundation and the English-language Wikipedia's WikiProject Medicine, among other groups. WHO began working with Wikipedia to provide much of its infographics and reports on COVID-19 to help fight misinformation, with plans to use similar approaches for fighting misinformation about other infectious diseases in the future. Newspapers and scholarly journals[ ] Initially, many newspapers with [paywalls](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/paywall) lowered them for some or all their coronavirus coverage. Many scientific publishers made scientific papers related to the outbreak [open access](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/open_access) (free). The scientific publishing community, while intent on producing quality scholarly publications, has itself been negatively impacted by the infiltration of inferior or false research leading to the retraction of several articles on the topic of COVID-19, as well as polluting valid and reliable scientific study, bringing into question the reliability of research undertaken. [Retraction Watch](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Retraction_Watch) maintains a database of retracted COVID-19 articles. Censorship[ ] A number of governments have made transmitting misinformation about the virus illegal. This may be the extent of the virus within a country, or the inadequacy of preparations for and measures taken against the virus. The [Turkish Interior Ministry](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_the_Interior_(Turkey)) has been [arresting](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Censorship_in_Turkey) social media users whose posts were "targeting officials and spreading panic and fear by suggesting the virus had spread widely in Turkey and that officials had taken insufficient measures". [Iran's military](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_the_Islamic_Republic_of_Iran) said 3600 people have been arrested for "spreading rumors" about coronavirus in the country. In [Cambodia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cambodia), some individuals who expressed concerns about the spread of COVID-19 have been arrested on fake news charges. Algerian lawmakers passed a law criminalising "fake news" deemed harmful to "public order Hong Kong, people have been arrested for allegedly spreading false information about the COVID-19 pandemic. The [United Arab Emirates](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates) has introduced criminal penalties for the spread of misinformation and rumours related to the outbreak. [Myanmar](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myanmar) blocked access to 221 news websites, including several leading media outlets. Scams[ ] The UN WHO has warned of criminal scams involving perpetrators who misrepresent themselves as representatives of the WHO seeking personal information from victims via email or phone. Also, the [Federal Communications Commission](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Communications_Commission) has advised consumers not to click on links in suspicious emails and not to give out personal information in emails, text messages or phone calls. The [Federal Trade Commission](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Trade_Commission) has also warned on charity scams related to the pandemic, and has advised consumers not to donate in cash, gift cards, or wire transfers. Cybersecurity firm [Check Point](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Check_Point) stated there has been a large increase in [phishing](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/phishing) attacks to lure victims into unwittingly installing a computer virus under the guise of coronavirus-themed emails containing attachments. Cyber-criminals use deceptive domains such as "cdc-gov.org" instead of the correct "cdc.gov", or even [spoof the original domain](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/domain_spoofing) so it resembles specific websites. More than 4,000 coronavirus-related domains have been registered. Police in New Jersey, United States reported incidents of criminals knocking on people's doors and claiming to be from the CDC. They then attempt to sell products at inflated prices or otherwise scam victims under the guise of educating and protecting the public from the coronavirus. Links that purportedly direct to the [Johns Hopkins University](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johns_Hopkins_University) coronavirus map, but instead direct to a false site that spreads [malware](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/malware), have been circulating on the Internet. Since the passage in March 2020 of the [CARES Act](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CARES_Act), criminals have taken advantage of the stimulus bill by asking people to pay in advance in order to receive their stimulus payment. Because of this, the IRS has advised consumers to only use the official IRS coronavirus web address to submit information to the IRS (and not in response to a text, email, or phone call). In response to these schemes, many financial companies, like [Wells Fargo](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wells_Fargo) and [LoanDepot](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LoanDepot), as well as health insurers, like [Humana](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humana), for example, have posted similar advisories on their websites.
